org.firstinspires.ftc.robotcontroller.external.samples

Class ConceptWebcam

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.OpMode
      • com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.LinearOpMode
        • org.firstinspires.ftc.robotcontroller.external.samples.ConceptWebcam

  • @TeleOp(name="Concept: Webcam",
        group="Concept")
 @Disabled
public class ConceptWebcam
extends com.qualcomm.robotcore.eventloop.opmode.LinearOpMode
    This OpMode illustrates how to open a webcam and retrieve images from it. It requires a configuration containing a webcam with the default name ("Webcam 1"). When the opmode runs, pressing the 'A' button will cause a frame from the camera to be written to a file on the device, which can then be retrieved by various means (e.g.: Device File Explorer in Android Studio; plugging the device into a PC and using Media Transfer; ADB; etc)

      • secondsPermissionTimeout

        private static final int secondsPermissionTimeout
        How long we are to wait to be granted permission to use the camera before giving up. Here, we wait indefinitely

      • frameQueue

        private org.firstinspires.ftc.robotcore.internal.collections.EvictingBlockingQueue<android.graphics.Bitmap> frameQueue
        The queue into which all frames from the camera are placed as they become available. Frames which are not processed by the OpMode are automatically discarded.

      • captureCounter

        private int captureCounter
        State regarding where and how to save frames when the 'A' button is pressed.

      • captureDirectory

        private java.io.File captureDirectory

      • callbackHandler

        private android.os.Handler callbackHandler
        A utility object that indicates where the asynchronous callbacks from the camera infrastructure are to run. In this OpMode, that's all hidden from you (but see startCamera() if you're curious): no knowledge of multi-threading is needed here.
